review.title: Irrespective Priority-Based Regular Properties of High-Intensity Virtual Environments
review.abstract: We have a lot of relation to the encoding and the Theory of Information, when considering thinking. This is a natural process and, at once, the complex thing we investigate. This always was a challenge - to understand how our mind works, and we are trying to find some universal models for this. A lot of ways have been considered so far, but we are looking for Something, we seek for approaches. And the goal is to find a consistent, noncontradictory view, which should at once be enough flexible in any dimensions to allow to represent various kinds of processes and environments, matters of different nature and diverse objects. Developing of such a model is the destination of this article.

sections.text: It was as challenging a challenge as you can imagine.

sections.heading: II. PROBLEM DESCRIPTION
sections.text: "Action expresses priorities." Mahatma GhandiImagine that we are looking on the basis of computational processes. Then, we should see a starting point of a task and a processing unit (as in today's architecture of computations), which will cause something like a bottleneck (fig. 1) that allows the task or data to pass through according to the capacity of that unit. Otherwise, this unit will in some way limit the computational capabilities of the system and let the process flow serially: Something greater should be expressed by something more narrow. The same situation in different forms that we observe in nature, and to a large extent it determines the appearance of the real world and the entire possible existence that we can observe. Other determines reality. It is that when we talk about interactions in any space, we must look at simultaneous objects with defined shapes and boundaries in relation to the environment.

sections.heading: III. LIMITATIONS OF PROCESSES
sections.text: This is the question that arises as to the extent to which this is a global problem that needs to be solved not only in Europe, but also in other parts of the world.

sections.heading: IV. ARCHITECTURE-DIRECTED OPTIMIZATION
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to determine for themselves what they want to do and what they want to do.

sections.heading: V. COMPREHENSION-BASED CONSTRUCTIONS
sections.text: In this section we will give the description of the architectures with the new properties we are developing. Let us consider the series of solutions. Each standpoint has several such solutions in a unique viewing space, and each of these solutions consists of some components that reflect their inner content: = {and, "", ""., "", "", "", "", "", "", "" "," "" and "and" and, "and" and, "and" and "and," and "and," and "and," and "and," and "and" and, "and" and, "and" and, "and," and, "and" and., "

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This work continues the research that has been done in [1], [4] - [6], and here we have taken a step forward in formalizing the independent properties of observable and conceivable spaces. This research can help us to understand more clearly what mind is, and we are no longer needed to address thinking only to the physical processes in certain tissues or organisms, or even to certain physical objects, and will be able to look beyond to the elementary properties of nature, which constitute the whole variety of other possible representations of reality and virtual spaces that may be both observable and existent or imaginable. In further research, we will continue to specify the spatial properties of reality and further formalize what we have found. The goal will be to connect what we already have, expand the basic concepts and concepts, cover the basic variant of a complete model, and achieve practical results in decision making, planning, analysis, automated design, effective reasoning, or optimization of the use of this theory or formation.

metadata.abstractText: We have a lot of relation to the encoding and the Theory of Information, when considering thinking. This is a natural process and, at once, the complex thing we investigate. This always was a challenge – to understand how our mind works, and we are trying to find some universal models for this. A lot of ways have been considered so far, but we are looking for Something, we seek for approaches. And the goal is to find a consistent, noncontradictory view, which should at once be enough flexible in any dimensions to allow to represent various kinds of processes and environments, matters of different nature and diverse objects by the singular apparatus. Developing of such a model is the destination of this article.
